page.title: 10Quarrying Cotswold Stone (1)
page.content: Huntsman Quarrry, started 50 years ago by a farming family who needed stone for their buildings and walls, now covers 50 hectares. There is enough stone left for another 30-40 years. The stone is sedimentary rock of the Jurassic series. There is one metre of stone made with minute shells. This is ground and used for limestone on the fields to adjust the acidity of the soil. Below that is 4 metres of Silicious limestone which is a hard stone ideal for road-building and bedding pipes. 2000 tons per day of this crushed stone, called fines, was being despatched as bedding for the lead-free petrol pipeline being constructed locally as part of a trunk line from Southampton-Wolverhampton.
